Favorite 'find' at an international market?
Fresh wasabi root at a market in Tokyo. Grating that into soy sauce for my sushi was an absolute revelation.

Favorite food experience under $10?
The perfect banh mi in Vietnam - crispy baguette piled with pork, pâté, pickled veggies, cilantro and jalapeño. Street food at its finest.

Essential contemporary cookbook?
Anything by the Swedish chef Magnus Nilsson. His books are like culinary anthropological studies - completely inspiring.

What's your favorite ingredient to cook with?
Nothing gets me more excited than a perfect, glistening slab of fatty tuna belly. I'll take sushi over steak any day.

Best food destination for a solo traveler?
Tokyo, without a doubt. Just lose yourself in the sensory overload of ramen counters, sushi bars, and yakitori spots.

Favorite international drink?
Irish coffee in a cozy Dublin pub. The interplay of rich coffee, Irish whiskey and lightly whipped cream is sublime.

Any tips for eating well while traveling?
Pack protein bars and avoid airport food at all costs! And when in doubt, follow the locals - they know where the good stuff is. My mantra is always "When in Rome, eat as the Romans do."

Most mind blowing ingredient you've discovered?
The funky fermented shrimp paste they use in Southeast Asian cooking. Repelled yet intrigued me at first, but now I'm hooked on its funky, umami goodness.

What's the best food city in the world?
I mean, how can you possibly pick just one? New York and Tokyo are up there. Bangkok blows my mind every time. But I've gotta give props to Chengdu. The fiery Sichuan cuisine just can't be beat.

Best city for a food tourist?
Throw a dart at a map of Thailand and you can't go wrong, but Bangkok is next level. From lacquered duck noodles to giant river prawns, it's a nonstop feast.

Where have you had the best pasta?
It's impossible to beat pasta in Rome. After an epic cacio e pepe at this tiny spot near the Pantheon, I wanted to renounce American citizenship and move in.
